Drosophila miranda is a species of fruit fly that belongs to the Drosophila genus. It is a small, two-winged insect with a typical fly-like appearance. The species is primarily found in North America, particularly in the western regions of the United States and Canada.

Drosophila miranda is known for its unique chromosomal characteristics. It has a diploid chromosome number of 12, with a karyotype that includes five large autosomes and a pair of sex chromosomes (X and Y). This species is of particular interest to researchers studying chromosomal evolution and speciation, as it exhibits a complex system of sex chromosome rearrangements and variations.

The life cycle of Drosophila miranda is similar to that of other Drosophila species, with a short generation time and high reproductive capacity. The females lay their eggs on rotting or fermenting plant matter, which serves as a food source for the developing larvae. The larvae undergo a series of molts and eventually pupate, with the adult flies emerging from the pupae.

Drosophila miranda has been widely used as a model organism in various scientific studies, particularly in the fields of genetics, evolutionary biology, and developmental biology. Its small size, rapid life cycle, and well-characterized genome make it a valuable tool for understanding fundamental biological processes and mechanisms.
